docs.lead_paragraph: LANE--Mark. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of Mark Lane, Fidelis Care President and CEO, who passed away unexpectedly on July 22. The tradition of the Catholic health care ministry found a new expression in Fidelis Care, and Mr. Lane guided the health plan to become an advocate, a resource, and an answer for uninsured children and adults of all ages. From the beginning, he expressed and instilled in each of us an uncommon passion for excellence, the highest attention to detail, and a steadfast commitment to the company's mission of serving the poor and most vulnerable with compassion, dignity, and respect. His vision for what Fidelis Care could be was realized not only in the company's growth and success over the years, but also in the lives that were changed by having access to quality, affordable health insurance. He cared about people from all walks of life - children, parents, college students, jobless adults who recently lost health insurance, the low-income elderly, residents of rural areas, and those in New York's largest cities - there was no population too small, no story too insignificant for his focus and attention. With one set of values, Mr. Lane lived life seamlessly. Whether as steward of a successful company, or as loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather, the same uncompromised principles prevailed. We are grateful for his vision and the standards and expectations he established, giving each of us a foundation upon which to build as we go forward, day by day. This is how we will honor him; he will never be forgotten. - The Board and Staff of Fidelis Care New York

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Congressional Budget Office said Tuesday that the Supreme Court decision on President Obama's health care overhaul would probably lead to an increase in the number of uninsured and a modest reduction in the cost to the federal government when compared with estimates before the court ruling. Of the 33 million people who had been expected to gain coverage under the law, 3 million fewer are now predicted to get insurance, the budget office said in assessing the likely effects of the court decision.

headline.main: Court's Ruling May Blunt Reach of the Health Law

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says Supreme Court decision on Pres Obama's health care overhaul will likely lead to an increase in the number of uninsured, with 3 million fewer predicted to get insurance out of the 33 million who had been expected to gain coverage; law is also expected to cost the government $84 billion less than previously estimated, a modest reduction. Graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A shift in social attitudes and an attractive price tag are helping turn the country into a global transgender surgery hub.

headline.seo: Serbia Becomes a Hub for Sex-Change Surgery
headline.main: Serbia Becomes a Hub for Sex-Change Surgery
headline.print_headline: As Attitudes Shift on Sex Changes, Serbia Becomes a Hub for Surgery

docs.abstract: People are coming from around the world to Serbia for sex change operations, as shifting social attitudes and low-cost procedures help turn the country into a global transgender surgery hub.

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have long known that increasing age is the strongest risk for a diagnosis of late-stage cervical cancer. Now a new study suggests that the next strongest risk is the patient's insurance status. Survival is strongly related to the stage at which cervical cancer is diagnosed. Women with early, localized lesions have five-year survival rates of 91.2 percent; just 17 percent of those with advanced, distant disease survive that long.

headline.main: Vital Signs | Prevention: Insurance Sways Risk of Cancer Diagnosis

docs.abstract: Stacey A Fedewa study in The American Journal of Public Health finds that uninsured women are far more likely to be diagnosed with late-stage cervical cancer than their insured counterparts. (M)/

docs.lead_paragraph: Striking workers at an Illinois factory are protesting a call by the construction equipment manufacturer for a six-year wage and pension freeze amid record profits.

headline.seo: Profitable Caterpillar Pushes Workers for Concessions
headline.main: At Caterpillar, Pressing Labor While Business Booms
headline.print_headline: At Caterpillar, Pressing Labor For Concessions

docs.abstract: Caterpillar company is insisting on a six-year wage freeze and a pension freeze for most of the production workers at its factory in Joliet, Ill, despite earning a record profit in 2011 and projecting even better results for 2012; company's stance has angered its workers, who have been on strike for 12 weeks; showdown is being closely watched by unions and corporations across the country.
docs.snippet: Striking workers at an Illinois factory are protesting a call by the construction equipment manufacturer for a six-year wage and pension freeze amid record profits.
